captions.text:
The debt limit is kind of a financial weapon
of mass destruction chained to the United
States government by the United States government.

Confused? Then it's time for The United States
debt limit Explained.

To understand the debt limit you need to know
the US splits financial responsibility between
the president and congress.

The president has two jobs when it comes to
money:

1. Collect taxes and...
2. Spend those taxes to run the government.

This might give you the impression that the
president, with regards to money, is all-powerful.

Especially when you hear news reports on 'the
president's new budget' or his plan to 'raise

taxes on haberdashers' or 'lower taxes on
apiarists'.

But reality is just the opposite and the president
is the one who takes orders.
From whom?
Congress.

Congress has the jobs of setting the tax level
and determining how much the government will
spend by writing a budget.

So while the president does get to submit
budgets to congress, and asks for changes

in the tax level, these are just requests
that congress doesn't have to pay attention
to.

Congress can add or subtract anything they
want from the president's budget or throw

it out entirely and write a new one. The same
goes for the level of taxes.

So congress decides what it wants: bridges,
tanks, buildings, courts, robots on Mars,

robots on Earth, National Parks, whatever
and approves a budget with that stuff in it.

Once approved the president's is required
by law to spend the money Congress listed

in the budget and pay for it using the taxes
that congress set.

As long as more taxes come in than spending
goes out everything is fine.

But, almost always, Congress puts more stuff
in the budget than they cover with taxes which

means the president must borrow money to cover
the difference.

In most countries the story ends here because
if their legislatures approved more spending

than they have income, they've also implicitly
approved the necessary borrowing -- but not

in America. Here Congress *also* limits the
total amount of debt the United States can
have.

A debt limit sounds like a good idea until
you see the real-world consequences of these
two branches of government interacting.

As the total amount borrowed gets closer to
the limit, Congress usually points to the

president and acts shocked, *shocked* that
his reckless spending has brought us so close

to the debt limit that they, reasonable, prudent
Congress have set.

And while it's technically correct that the
president has borrowed this money, congress

has forced him to do it, by approving a budget
that the president is legally obligated to

spend without also approving the necessary
taxes to cover that spending.

So the debt limit fight is essentially the
government version of the playground favorite:

'stop hitting yourself' except with added
terror for everyone watching.

For, it's important to note, the debt limit
is not about future spending -- it's not a

credit card on which the limit will be raised
so a crazy government party can be thrown

-- the debt limit is about paying bills already
incurred.

For example, the government hires a company
to repave a federal highway. But if the US

is at the debt limit, when the company asks
to be paid after the work has been done, the

government can't. This shakes trust in the
US and since large parts of the global economy

depend on the dollar being trust worthy, messing
with that trust is a big deal.

But there is a way out: Congress can raise
the debt limit and, because of the aforementioned
terror, they always have.

So… if not raising the debt ceiling is potentially
disastrous and the solution is simple and

always taken in the end: *why does this debate
last months‽*
Because: politics.

The debt limit isn't in the constitution,
congress created it themselves and from their
point of view, the debt limit is awesome because:

1. It creates a problem that
2. Congress can (technically) blame on the

president who
3. Needs the solution that only they can provide

Congress gets to use the threat of mutual
financial self destruction as leverage in

negations that they benefit from extending
until the last… possible… second.

comments.author: Adnan Aouad

comments.text:
There's a *larger* point.  The US "borrows", i.e. sells Treasury Bonds to 
the investor world, thru a set of Primary Dealer private banks and 
financial institutions, *only* because Congress *requires* that Treasury 
provide those savings account vehicles for the financial sector, as a *tool* 
for the financial sector to *operate itself*, including managing to keep 
base interest rates propped up above zero.

The US govt "borrows" because it is Congress policy that the US *must* 
"borrow" from banks and other entities like foreign central banks, not 
because it functionally needs to "get" US dollars from outside institutions 
which *do not create a single US dollar*, merely because this is part of 
the convoluted methods that Congress has chosen to use to balance the 
global financial system which the US dominates.

Taxes do not actually fund spending.  Spending functionally occurs when 
Treasury is authorized by instructions from Congress to issue instructions 
to the Fed to add numbers to the back room reserve accounts of banks, which 
are accounts that exist on the Fed's own computers.  Some mathematical 
addition is performed, then some recipient has a larger checking acct 
balance, with money that sprang into existence OUTSIDE of the govt based on 
the lawful powers of Treasury officers to do math.

For taxes, the private sector issues instructions for the Fed to do 
subtraction of dollars from the private sector.  That subtraction really 
does not give the US govt any "funds", at least none that it could not 
create without tax collection.

One way to look at it fundamentally, is Treasury "borrows" from the Fed by 
each swapping a kind of note, a routine paper swap like Wall St does daily 
and hourly.  Only Congress insists that the Fed is forbidden to swap paper 
directly with Treasury, and must use other private banks to do the paper 
swap.  Even tho these private banks can legally borrow from the Fed or do 
an overdraft, Treasury is forbidden by Congress from doing an overdraft on 
its Fed account.

So it LOOKS LIKE borrowing to fund federal spending, but it isn't that, not 
anymore, not since the Gold Std debt ceiling was abolished by Nixon in 1972 
and halfway abolished by FDR in 1933.﻿

This is generally a good video, but it would have been better had there 
been mention of impoundment, the Nixon era change to the process that 
required the executive branch to spend the entire amount of money in the 
budget on everything in the budget. Prior to that change, the Congress only 
set maximal limits and the President might decide to not pay for an entire 
department and essentially close it down.﻿

comments.text:
+Keith Voltaire Sort of... You have to be weary of these politicians. Many 
politicians will speak of "buckling down and keeping a balanced budget by 
not raising the debt limit." They don't understand that by NOT raising the 
debt limit, the United States will default on its "debt" to the Federal 
Reserve (the "debt" which i speak of is the very money you have in your 
wallet). HOWEVER, by continuously RAISING the debt limit, we are slowly 
crippling our monetary supply...it will eventually collapse under its own 
weight as we borrow more and more money to try to pay off the previous 
money already borrowed. 

The monetary system of the United States has us all by the balls; it was 
not designed to be a sustainable system. Our entire economy is one big, 
over-inflated balloon which will keep on inflating until it pops. And when 
that happens, my friend, shit is going to hit the fan...HARD.

comments.author: Rod Martin, Jr.

comments.text:
Being freed from being sued for injury by a product, doesn't mean the 
product is harmful. Anyone can file a lawsuit, and Monsanto would have to 
address it in court.  The costliness of a protracted legal battle with 
hundreds or thousands of people convinced that they've been harmed by 
Monsanto would hurt their profit margin, even if the claims were completely 
baseless.  If it ever got in front of a jury, America as a whole is so 
science-phobic that they'd automatically assume that GMO's are bad and 
Monsanto would essentially have to try to prove that GMO's are harmless, 
which is a lot like proving a negative.

comments.text:
+The Soft Glow of Brightly Burning Hope That's not Capitalism.

What many people mix up these days it Capitalism, and Corporatism.

Capitalism is simply free markets, that have minimal Government Regulation, 
and low Government spending, and as low of taxes as possible.

Corporatism is always the direct result of Big Government. Corporatist 
Government often start out socialist, so the government has lots of power, 
and spends and taxes a lot. Corporatism is where the Government takes 
"Bribes" from Corporation, and Gives them huge benefits and Unnatural 
powers, in the form of Subsidies, bailouts, and other things.

So the issue with money in politics is an issue with corporatism, not 
Capitalism. We haven't had Capitalism since the early 1900's actually.

comments.text:
The congress IS America you dumb twit. It consists of 535 members made to 
represent you and I. The only reason it isn't doing that very well is 
because it has lost the ability to print it's own money and so instead has 
to rely on outside entities to get paid.

Only a tiny fraction of those entities consist of "Corporate bullies" which 
pale in comparison to the biggest bully of all since 1913: the Federal 
Reserve, which acts completely independent of our government.

So you see, it is not the large group of senators and house representatives 
which WE OURSELVES freely elect which are holding the nation hostage. That 
title can instead go to the practically foreign entity that controls the 
ability to print dollar bills, and then choose when and when not to 
circulate those dollar bills using our government.

We don't have to fight a revolution in order to rid ourselves of the FED, 
all we have to do is have the courage and competency to stand up for 
ourselves by electing a leader that will say out loud that he plans to use 
congress to print his own currency, owned by the people (the congress), and 
then stand behind that leader in his decision by selling our old federal 
reserve notes for the new government bills.

Here's a quick history lesson for you. The last three presidents to 
successfully do this: President Lincoln, Andrew Jackson, and John F Kennedy 
where all assassinated! Jackson wasn't assassinated only because both the 
pistols of his assassin jammed at the same time! These presidents weren't 
assassinated by hateful members of the public acting under a belief of 
injustice, they where carried out by greedy assholes that would have lost 
all the wealth they stole by controlling the currency used by the public.

And shame on you for thinking that the president should just run the 
country, the USA is not a monarchy!

comments.author: Ariel Schwartz

comments.text:
One important piece of information that Grey left out of this video is that 
the United States is an issuer of sovereign currency.  This means that (in 
the absence of politicians acting like idiots and intentionally deciding 
not to pay something) as long as a debt is denominated in U.S. dollars the 
federal government can technically pay for it.  Heck, most of the federal 
debt is owed back to the federal government.   The problem isn't solvency 
as much as it is the value of money.  If we buy too much crap and run the 
deficit too high we risk serious inflation problems (see post WW I 
Germany), if we don't spend anything then we run into deflation and make 
new business ventures too expensive to start and slow our economy to a 
grinding halt.  If this claim sounds ridiculous to you get acquainted with 
the Sectoral Balances Model, read Understanding the Modern Monetary System 
by Cullen Roche, both describe government spending better than anything you 
are likely to have encountered in your life.﻿

+The Urban Wolf Precisely.

I neither slandered Capitalism nor endorsed Socialism. I simply maintain

This debate has been mature and informative. And for that I thank you.

comments.text:
+whynot-tomorrow? I said that some Regulation is completely necessary.

Capitalism is Simple, and it works.

The Economy Wouldn't change really. It's just that it all revolves around 
people buying and selling. If people don't want something, it becomes too 
expensive to see it, and it is discontinued.

This is the most Natural system out there.

Socialism is the cause of Corruption by Corporations because you have this 
Big Government who can dispense benefits and tax breaks, and bailouts to 
Companies.

Capitalism is all about Removing most Government intervention, weather that 
be Corporate Welfare, or Corporate Regulation.
comments.author: The Urban Wolf

comments.text:
+The Urban Wolf Thank you.

Are you sure you disagree? I believe that some regulation is immensely 
beneficial, especially in regards to the aforementioned monopolization of 
markets, which is the literal corruption of any Capitalist economy.

Regardless of these good intentions, the most influential interest groups 
such as arms manufacturers, banking, and insurance companies, are able to 
take advantage of an overly generous system of bailouts and tax breaks.

The distinction I am forced to make coincides with the definition of 
"Utopian Capitalism" and the establishment thereof. "Utopia," as a 
political system, is often misconstrued as the 'perfect world,' while, in 
fact, its original meaning was 'the world that cannot exist.' I maintain 
that this Darwinistic, evolving economy you propose cannot come to fruition 
within the confines of human nature. People resist. They are stubborn. The 
same industrialists who exploit the current system are more likely to 
preserve their own lucrative existence than submit to a fully equalized 
system. Such efforts could very well manifest themselves as political 
action and even the implementation of new economic regulation.

The people most capable of influencing policy are the least likely to 
reform a system in which they benefit from its shortcomings. 

==========================

As a side note, all this business about "sympathy" is more tiring than 
constructive. 

I meant it more in regards to utilitarianism than actual economic practice. 

So....really....whatevs.....discussion for another day.
comments.author: whynot-tomorrow?

comments.text:
+whynot-tomorrow? Well said.

I must disagree. Capitalism simply lets the economy rise to it's full 
potential, with SOME Necessary regulation. It puts everyone on the same 
playing field, unlike socialism, which allows the government to dispense 
benefits to corporations that others don't get.

Under Capitalism, we would see a Boom in industry, and the markets. The 
Economy would improve slowly over time. 

We wouldn't, however, see a domination of big corporations, we would all be 
playing on the same field. Of Course Corporations will do well. However, 
they wouldn't get these ridiculous benefits that the government dispenses 
these days.

Sympathy shouldn't be mentioned in a Market. Sympathy to the poor 
specifically comes from PEOPLE, not a market.

The Government's job isn't to take care of us, and take money from the 
rich, and give it too the poor.

By the way, Capitalism is not a Utopian system. Capitalism doesn't seek a 
utopia, as Communism does. Capitalism is for freedom, and Liberty.
comments.author: The Urban Wolf
